SMEC Administration

post_text: SMEC would like to thank the Spring Valley Kiwanis for their generous donation of $250 towards the purchase of the consortium's OAE device. The Otoacoustic emissions (OAE) device allows our early childhood educators to screen students to determine if there are any hearing problems that may impact the child's development. It lets the team determine within seconds if there are no concerns with the child's hearing or if the family may have to seek follow up medical care with an audiologist. Thank you so much for this contribution towards our students!

post_text: Students in the Next STEP Transition Program West located in Alden, MN have been busy this past week on another project. They have been working with the consortium's Early Childhood teachers and Occupational Therapists to create sensory boards for the center-based preschool programs located in SMEC. The students planned the layouts of the board, went shopping for the items, and have been busy this week painting and attaching the objects to the boards. Once the boards are completed they will deliver the sensory boards to the preschool programs. A sensory board is basically a board on which you attach tactile and visual objects to be explored. Sensory boards are often used for young children to encourage stimulation of the senses and exploration through sensory play, a natural part of child development. The Transition students have really enjoyed being creative and being able to provide a fun educational tool for the younger students. We are very excited to see the finished projects!

post_text: Our students in the CARDS Middle School/High School summer school program had a variety of experiences to support learning in July. We worked on some practical cooking skills by making no churn ice cream and salsa. We learned about color theory and tie-dyed shirts. Lastly, we had the opportunity to read about and use observational skills as we watched Monarch butterflies in all parts of their life cycle and their habitats. We had eggs hatch, our caterpillars grew through five instars (stages of growth), they entered the pupal stage and we waited for those chrysalis‚Äô to become adult butterflies. We released two adult butterflies and there were many more in the chrysalis stage by the time we left. The school at Grand Meadow (where summer school was for this program) is surrounded by milkweed and had an excellent habitat for this experience.

post_text: With April being Autism Awareness Month, we would like to share a few images that help better understand autism. Friday Spotlight time! This school year we introduced school based mental health services for our level 3 students. School based mental health services work to improve clinical and functional outcomes for children and youth with a mental health diagnosis. Untreated mental health issues are a significant barrier to learning and educational success. Having school based mental health services provides the opportunity for mental health promotion, prevention and early identification and intervention. Our team provides direct child and family services including assessment and treatment and they also provide teacher consultation and care coordination.

Thank you to this wonderful team for all that they do for our students!
